Author: staunch
Content:
No one seems to care, there's such a dire need for his site and no clear alternative.

Read his disclosure at the bottom of http://www.techcrunch.com/about-techcrunch/

He's gotten involved with a lot of startups he has profiled and heavily leverages his position to push his investments.

Author: staunch
Content: Wish I could vote it up 10 times. Best. Post. Evar.

Author: danielha
Content: Actually, it was probably Jason crawling news.yc indexing everything...

Author: staunch
Content:
"...not the ones that are ugly because there was no money to hire a designer, or because the programmer thought he was a designer."

Like Google or Craigslist? Necessity is not only the mother of invention, it seems to have another child: great design.

Author: daliso
Content:
I would tend to agree with this. On first site, virb doesn't seem like a site where the content is produced by ordinary people. If I had no experience with the web or design, I would be kind of shy to upload my content as it might look too scruffy for such a polished site.

On the other hand, the sheer scruffiness of a myspace and some of the content on there drastically lowers the perceived entry standards for one to participate. Therefore you have more people unashamed to put up their poorly designed sites.

Author: python_kiss
Title: Google's CPA Move: Will Microsoft & Yahoo Have To Buy Their Way Into CPA Game?

Author: staunch
Content:
I don't think you have to quantify anything, it's not a matter of science or math -- it's about how much that money means to you.

Just imagine some rich guy with a checkbook. Imagine what the minimum number he has to write in order to take your three month old baby. It's a realistic situation and the guy with the checkbook isn't going to pay you what you "want" he's going to pay you what you won't say "no" to.

Assume it's a cash only deal, but figure that if it's Google you'd go even lower on cash if it meant you have a sweet job and salary -- that's obvious.
